PageTitle: section lock (Global CGN address pool view)
FuncDef:
The section lock command locks an address segment in a global static address pool.
The undo section lock unlocks an address segment in a global static address pool.
By default, no address segment in a global static address pool is locked.

ParaDef.Info:
Specifies the ID of an address segment to be locked in the global static address pool.
The value is an integer ranging from 0 to 255.

ExtraInfo:
Usage Scenario
After the nat outbound command is run in the NAT instance view to configure a NAT conversion policy, you can run the section command to add an address segment to the address pool. However, using the undo section command to delete an address segment is not allowed.
Due to reasons such as service planning, an address segment sometimes needs to be deleted from a NAT address pool. In this case, run the section lock command to lock the address segment first. Then, run the reset nat user nat-ip-pool section command to forcibly make all the NAT users whose IP addresses are in the address segment to go offline. After all the users using the public IP address in the address segment go offline, that is, the public IP address is not allocated to any user, run the undo section command to delete the address segment.
Prerequisites
A global static address pool and an address segment need to be configured.
Configuration Impact
After the address segment of a global static address pool is locked, addresses in the segment cannot be assigned to users.
Precautions
This command is applicable only to the VSUF-80/VSUF-160/VSUI-160-E/VSUI-400/VSUI-400-E/VSUI-400A/VSUI-400A-E/VSUI-400-S/VSUI-400A-S.
After the section lock command is run in a NAT instance address pool, the public network resources allocated from this address segment will not be automatically reclaimed, and the available public network resources will not be allocated to new online users. During calculation of the address pool usage, the public network resources that have not been allocated are also counted in the total public network resources but will not be allocated to new online users. The calculation formula of the address pool usage is as follows: Number of allocated public network resources / Total number of public network resources (the public network resources here indicate the public IP addresses or ports). The obtained address pool usage may not reflect the real address allocation status and may affect the address pool usage query result and the corresponding threshold-crossing alarm. After the section lock command is run, you are advised to run the reset nat user nat-ip-pool section command to forcibly make all NAT users with the public IP address in the address segment to go offline as soon as possible. After ensuring that public IP address in the address segment is not allocated to any user, run the undo section command to delete the address segment.
In the inter-chassis backup scenario, the section lock command can be run after both the master and slave chassis are configured with the section lock command. After the operation is performed, run the undo section lock command on both the master and slave chassis to ensure configuration consistency.
